contentrichtext.text: {{otherships|USS Lawrence}} {|{{Infobox Ship Begin}} {{Infobox Ship Image |Ship image=[[Image:USS Lawrence 1875 NH51253 crop.jpg|300px]] |Ship caption=Raised hulk of the USS ''Lawrence'', Misery Bay, Erie, Pennsylvania, 1875 }} {{Infobox Ship Career |Hide header= |Ship country=USA |Ship flag={{USN flag|1815}} |Ship name= |Ship namesake=[[James Lawrence]] |Ship awarded=18 February 1813 |Ship builder=Adam and Noah Brown |Ship laid down= |Ship launched=24 May 1813 |Ship acquired= |Ship commissioned=August 1813 |Ship decommissioned= |Ship in service= |Ship out of service=1815 |Ship struck= |Ship honors= |Ship fate=Sunk for preservation 1815, raised 1875, lost in 1876 fire |Ship status= |Ship notes= }} {{Infobox Ship Characteristics |Hide header= |Header caption= |Ship class= |Ship displacement=493 tons |Ship length={{convert|109|ft|9|in|abbr=on}} |Ship beam={{convert|16|ft|3|in|abbr=on}} |Ship draft={{convert|4|ft|8|in|abbr=on}} |Ship propulsion=Sail |Ship speed= |Ship complement=134 |Ship armament=2 x long 12-pounders, 18 x short 32-pounder cannonades |Ship notes= }} |} '''USS ''Lawrence''''' was one of two 493-ton ''Niagara''-class [[brig]]s (more correctly: [[Snow (ship)|snows]]) built at [[Erie, Pennsylvania]], by [[Adam Brown (shipwright)|Adam]] and [[Noah Brown]] under the supervision of [[Sailing Master]] [[Daniel Dobbins]] and [[Master Commandant]] [[Oliver Hazard Perry]], for [[United States Navy]] service on the [[Great Lakes]] during the [[War of 1812]]. She was commissioned in early August 1813 and quickly began operations with a voyage to [[Detroit, Michigan]] in search of the opposing British squadron. During the 10 September 1813 [[Battle of Lake Erie]], ''Lawrence'' served as [[flagship]] for Perry until she was disabled by enemy fire. Perry then transferred to her sister-ship, the [[USS Niagara (1813)|''Niagara'']], from which he fought the battle to a successful conclusion. In mid-1815, following the end of hostilities, ''Lawrence'' was sunk in Misery Bay on [[Presque Isle State Park|Presque Isle, PA]] in order to preserve her hull. Her submerged hulk was sold in 1825 and, except for a brief examination in 1836, remained underwater for five more decades. In September 1875, her remains were raised, cut into sections and transported by rail to [[Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]] where she was exhibited during [[Centennial Exposition|The U.S. Centennial International Exhibition of 1876]].
